title: 莊子
source: Chinese Text Project (ctext.org) - James Legge translation

chapter.title: Normal Course For Rulers And Kings

passages.zh: 齧缺問於王倪，四問而四不知。
passages.en: Nie Que put four questions to Wang Ni, not one of which did he know (how to answer).

passages.zh: 齧缺因躍而大喜，行以告蒲衣子。
passages.en: On this Nie Que leaped up, and in great delight walked away and informed Yu-yi Zi of it, who said to him, 'Do you (only) now know it?'

passages.zh: 蒲衣子曰：「而乃今知之乎？
passages.en: He of the line of Yu was not equal to him of the line of Tai.

passages.zh: 有虞氏不及泰氏。
passages.en: He of Yu still kept in himself (the idea of) benevolence by which to constrain (the submission of) men; and he did win men, but he had not begun to proceed by what did not belong to him as a man.

passages.zh: 有虞氏，其猶藏仁以要人，亦得人矣，而未始出於非人。
passages.en: He of the line of Tai would sleep tranquilly, and awake in contented simplicity.

passages.zh: 泰氏，其臥徐徐，其覺于于，一以己為馬，一以己為牛，其知情信，其德甚真，而未始入於非人。」
passages.en: He would consider himself now (merely) as a horse, and now (merely) as an ox. His knowledge was real and untroubled by doubts; and his virtue was very true: he had not begun to proceed by what belonged to him as a man.

passages.zh: 肩吾見狂接輿。
passages.en: Jian Wu went to see the mad (recluse), Jie-yu, who said to him, 'What did Ri-Zhong Shi tell you?'

passages.zh: 狂接輿曰：「日中始何以語女？」
passages.en: The reply was, 'He told me that when rulers gave forth their regulations according to their own views and enacted righteous measures, no one would venture not to obey them, and all would be transformed.'

passages.zh: 肩吾曰：「告我：君人者，以己出經式義度，人孰敢不聽而化諸！」
passages.en: Jie-yu said, 'That is but the hypocrisy of virtue.

passages.zh: 狂接輿曰：「是欺德也。
passages.en: For the right ordering of the world it would be like trying to wade through the sea and dig through the He, or employing a mosquito to carry a mountain on its back.

passages.zh: 其於治天下也，猶涉海鑿河，而使蚉負山也。
passages.en: And when a sage is governing, does he govern men's outward actions?

passages.zh: 夫聖人之治也，治外乎？
passages.en: He is (himself) correct, and so (his government) goes on; this is the simple and certain way by which he secures the success of his affairs.

passages.zh: 正而後行，確乎能其事者而已矣。
passages.en: Think of the bird which flies high, to avoid being hurt by the dart on the string of the archer, and the little mouse which makes its hole deep under Shen-qiu to avoid the danger of being smoked or dug out; are (rulers) less knowing than these two little creatures?'

passages.zh: 且鳥高飛以避矰弋之害，鼷鼠深穴乎神丘之下，以避熏鑿之患，而曾二蟲之無知！」
passages.en: Tian Gen, rambling on the south of (mount) Yin, came to the neighbourhood of the Liao-water.

passages.zh: 天根遊於殷陽，至蓼水之上，適遭無名人而問焉，曰：「請問為天下。」
passages.en: Happening there to meet with the man whose name is not known, he put a question to him, saying, 'I beg to ask what should be done in order to (carry on) the government of the world.'

passages.zh: 無名人曰：「去！
passages.en: The nameless man said, 'Go away; you are a rude borderer.

passages.zh: 汝鄙人也，何問之不豫也！
passages.en: Why do you put to me a question for which you are unprepared?

passages.zh: 予方將與造物者為人，厭則又乘夫莽眇之鳥，以出六極之外，而遊無何有之鄉，以處壙埌之野。
passages.en: I would simply play the part of the Maker of (all) things. When wearied, I would mount on the bird of the light and empty air, proceed beyond the six cardinal points, and wander in the region of nonentity, to dwell in the wilderness of desert space.

passages.zh: 汝又何帠以治天下感予之心為？」
passages.en: What method have you, moreover, for the government of the world that you (thus) agitate my mind?'

passages.zh: 又復問。
passages.en: (Tian Gen), however, again asked the question, and the nameless man said, 'Let your mind find its enjoyment in pure simplicity; blend yourself with (the primary) ether in idle indifference; allow all things to take their natural course; and admit no personal or selfish consideration - do this and the world will be governed.'

passages.zh: 無名人曰：「汝遊心於淡，合氣於漠，順物自然，而無容私焉，而天下治矣。」
passages.en: Yang Zi-ju, having an interview with Lao Dan, said to him, 'Here is a man, alert and vigorous in responding to all matters, clearsighted and widely intelligent, and an unwearied student of the Dao - can he be compared to one of the intelligent kings?'

passages.zh: 陽子居見老聃曰：「有人於此，嚮疾強梁，物徹疏明，學道不倦。
passages.en: The reply was, 'Such a man is to one of the intelligent kings but as the bustling underling of a court who toils his body and distresses his mind with his various contrivances.

passages.zh: 如是者，可比明王乎？」
passages.en: And moreover, it is the beauty of the skins of the tiger and leopard which makes men hunt them; the agility of the monkey, or (the sagacity of) the dog that catches the yak, which make men lead them in strings; but can one similarly endowed be compared to the intelligent kings?'

passages.zh: 老聃曰：「是於聖人也，胥易技係，勞形怵心者也。
passages.en: Yang Zi-ju looked discomposed and said, 'I venture to ask you what the government of the intelligent kings is.'

passages.zh: 且也虎豹之文來田，猿狙之便、執嫠之狗來藉。
passages.en: Lao Dan replied, 'In the governing of the intelligent kings, their services overspread all under the sky, but they did not seem to consider it as proceeding from themselves; their transforming influence reached to all things, but the people did not refer it to them with hope.

passages.zh: 如是者，可比明王乎？」
passages.en: No one could tell the name of their agency, but they made men and things be joyful in themselves.

passages.zh: 陽子居蹴然曰：「敢問明王之治。」
passages.en: Where they took their stand could not be fathomed, and they found their enjoyment in (the realm of) nonentity.'

passages.zh: 老聃曰：「明王之治，功蓋天下而似不自己，化貸萬物而民弗恃，有莫舉名，使物自喜，立乎不測，而遊於無有者也。」
passages.en: In Zheng there was a mysterious wizard called Ji-xian.

passages.zh: 鄭有神巫曰季咸，知人之生死存亡，禍福壽夭，期以歲月旬日，若神。
passages.en: He knew all about the deaths and births of men, their preservation and ruin, their misery and happiness, and whether their lives would be long or short, foretelling the year, the month, the decade and the day like a spirit.

passages.zh: 鄭人見之，皆棄而走。
passages.en: When the people of Kang saw him, they all ran out of his way.

passages.zh: 列子見之而心醉，歸以告壺子，曰：「始吾以夫子之道為至矣，則又有至焉者矣。」
passages.en: Liezi went to see him, and was fascinated by him. Returning, he told Hu-zi of his interview, and said, 'I considered your doctrine, my master, to be perfect, but I have found another which is superior to it.'

passages.zh: 壺子曰：「吾與汝既其文，未既其實，而固得道與？」
passages.en: Hu-zi replied, 'I have communicated to you but the outward letter of my doctrine, and have not communicated its reality and spirit; and do you think that you are in possession of it?

passages.zh: 眾雌而無雄，而又奚卵焉！
passages.en: However many hens there be, if there be not the cock among them, how should they lay (real) eggs?

passages.zh: 而以道與世亢必信，夫故使人得而相女。
passages.en: When you confront the world with your doctrine, you are sure to show in your countenance (all that is in your mind), and so enable (this) man to succeed in interpreting your physiognomy.

passages.zh: 嘗試與來，以予示之。」
passages.en: Try and come to me with him, that I may show myself to him.'

passages.zh: 明日，列子與之見壺子。
passages.en: On the morrow, accordingly, Liezi came with the man and saw Hu-zi.

passages.zh: 出而謂列子曰：「嘻！
passages.en: When they went out, the wizard said, 'Alas!

passages.zh: 子之先生死矣，弗活矣，不以旬數矣！
passages.en: your master is a dead man. He will not live;-- not for ten days more!

passages.zh: 吾見怪焉，見溼灰焉。」
passages.en: I saw something strange about him - I saw the ashes (of his life) all slaked with water!'

passages.zh: 列子入，泣涕沾襟，以告壺子。
passages.en: When Liezi reentered, he wept till the front of his jacket was wet with his tears, and told Hu-zi what the man had said.

passages.zh: 壺子曰：「鄉吾示之以地文，萌乎不震不正。
passages.en: Hu-zi said, 'I showed myself to him with the forms of (vegetation beneath) the earth.

passages.zh: 是殆見吾杜德機也。
passages.en: There were the sprouts indeed, but without (any appearance of) growth or regularity:-- he seemed to see me with the springs of my (vital) power closed up.

passages.zh: 嘗又與來。」
passages.en: Try and come to me with him again.'

passages.zh: 明日，又與之見壺子。
passages.en: Next day, accordingly, Liezi brought the man again and saw Hu-zi.

passages.zh: 出而謂列子曰：「幸矣！
passages.en: When they went out, the man said, 'It is a fortunate thing for your master that he met with me.

passages.zh: 子之先生遇我也。
passages.en: He will get better; he has all the signs of living!

passages.zh: 有瘳矣，全然有生矣。
passages.en: I saw the balance (of the springs of life) that had been stopped (inclining in his favour).'

passages.zh: 吾見其杜權矣。」
passages.en: Liezi went in, and reported these words to his master, who said, 'I showed myself to him after the pattern of the earth (beneath the) sky.

passages.zh: 列子入，以告壺子。
passages.en: Neither semblance nor reality entered (into my exhibition), but the springs (of life) were issuing from beneath my feet;-- he seemed to see me with the springs of vigorous action in full play.

passages.zh: 壺子曰：「鄉吾示之以天壤，名實不入，而機發於踵。
passages.en: Try and come with him again.'

passages.zh: 是殆見吾善者機也。
passages.en: Next day Liezi came with the man again, and again saw Hu-zi with him.

passages.zh: 嘗又與來。」
passages.en: When they went out, the wizard said, 'Your master is never the same.

passages.zh: 明日，又與之見壺子。
passages.en: I cannot understand his physiognomy.

passages.zh: 出而謂列子曰：「子之先生不齊，吾無得而相焉。
passages.en: Let him try to steady himself, and I will again view him.'

passages.zh: 試齊，且復相之。」
passages.en: Liezi went in and reported this to Hu-zi, who said, 'This time I showed myself to him after the pattern of the grand harmony (of the two elemental forces), with the superiority inclining to neither.

passages.zh: 列子入，以告壺子。
passages.en: He seemed to see me with the springs of (vital) power in equal balance.

passages.zh: 壺子曰：「吾鄉示之以太沖莫勝。
passages.en: Where the water wheels about from (the movements of) a dugong, there is an abyss; where it does so from the arresting (of its course), there is an abyss; where it does so, and the water keeps flowing on, there is an abyss.

passages.zh: 是殆見吾衡氣機也。
passages.en: There are nine abysses with their several names, and I have only exhibited three of them.

passages.zh: 鯢桓之審為淵，止水之審為淵，流水之審為淵。
passages.en: Try and come with him again.'

passages.zh: 淵有九名，此處三焉。
passages.en: Next day they came, and they again saw Hu-zi.

passages.zh: 嘗又與來。」
passages.en: But before he had settled himself in his position, the wizard lost himself and ran away.

passages.zh: 明日，又與之見壺子。
passages.en: 'Pursue him,' said Hu-zi, and Liezi did so, but could not come up with him.

passages.zh: 立未定，自失而走。
passages.en: He returned, and told Hu-zi, saying, 'There is an end of him; he is lost; I could not find him.'

passages.zh: 壺子曰：「追之！」
passages.en: Hu-zi rejoined, 'I was showing him myself after the pattern of what was before I began to come from my author.

passages.zh: 列子追之不及，反以報壺子，曰：「已滅矣，已失矣，吾弗及也。」
passages.en: I confronted him with pure vacancy, and an easy indifference.

passages.zh: 壺子曰：「鄉吾示之以未始出吾宗。
passages.en: He did not know what I meant to represent.

passages.zh: 吾與之虛而委蛇，不知其誰何，因以為弟靡，因以為波流，故逃也。」
passages.en: Now he thought it was the idea of exhausted strength, and now that of an onward flow, and therefore he ran away.'

passages.zh: 然後列子自以為未始學而歸，三年不出。
passages.en: After this, Liezi considered that he had not yet begun to learn (his master's doctrine). He returned to his house, and for three years did not go out.

passages.zh: 為其妻爨，食豕如食人。
passages.en: He did the cooking for his wife. He fed the pigs as if he were feeding men.

passages.zh: 於事無與親，彫琢復朴，塊然獨以其形立。
passages.en: He took no part or interest in occurring affairs. He put away the carving and sculpture about him, and returned to pure simplicity. Like a clod of earth he stood there in his bodily presence.

passages.zh: 紛而封哉，一以是終。
passages.en: Amid all distractions he was (silent) and shut up in himself. And in this way he continued to the end of his life.

passages.zh: 無為名尸，無為謀府，無為事任，無為知主。
passages.en: Non-action (makes its exemplifier) the lord of all fame; non-action (serves him as) the treasury of all plans; non-action (fits him for) the burden of all offices; non-action (makes him) the lord of all wisdom.

passages.zh: 體盡無窮，而遊無朕，盡其所受於天，而無見得，亦虛而已。
passages.en: The range of his action is inexhaustible, but there is nowhere any trace of his presence. He fulfils all that he has received from Heaven, but he does not see that he was the recipient of anything. A pure vacancy (of all purpose) is what characterises him.

passages.zh: 至人之用心若鏡，不將不迎，應而不藏，故能勝物而不傷。
passages.en: When the perfect man employs his mind, it is a mirror. It conducts nothing and anticipates nothing; it responds to (what is before it), but does not retain it. Thus he is able to deal successfully with all things, and injures none.

passages.zh: 南海之帝為儵，北海之帝為忽，中央之帝為渾沌。
passages.en: The Ruler of the Southern Ocean was Shu, the Ruler of the Northern Ocean was Hu, and the Ruler of the Centre was Chaos.

passages.zh: 儵與忽時相與遇於渾沌之地，渾沌待之甚善。
passages.en: Shu and Hu were continually meeting in the land of Chaos, who treated them very well.

passages.zh: 儵與忽謀報渾沌之德，曰：「人皆有七竅，以視聽食息，此獨無有，嘗試鑿之。」
passages.en: They consulted together how they might repay his kindness, and said, 'Men all have seven orifices for the purpose of seeing, hearing, eating, and breathing, while this (poor) Ruler alone has not one. Let us try and make them for him.'

passages.zh: 日鑿一竅，七日而渾沌死。
passages.en: Accordingly they dug one orifice in him every day; and at the end of seven days Chaos died.
